items.item_details: Education Code Section 72122 provides that student disciplinary matters be considered by the Board of Trustees in closed session unless the student submits a written request to the Board Secretary that the hearing of the governing board be held as a public meeting.  As of the time of posting the agenda, no such request had been received; however, the deadline for submission of the request had not yet passed.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that is not satisfactory for further use by the District. California Education Code sections 81450 – 81452 provide that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use. The estimated aggregate resale value is greater than $5,000.00.
	 
District staff will assess and identify the most efficient manner to disposition the surplus that is in the best interest of the District and in accordance with California Education Code.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to arrange for the sale, donation, recycle, or disposal of the surplus in accordance with the procedures set forth in Education Code sections 81450-81452.
items.item_text: Sell, Donate, Recycle or Dispose of District Surplus

Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for curriculum additions and changes for the 2016-17 Catalog. Per Title 5 direction, all course changes, substantial and non-substantial, must be approved by the governing board of the District before they may be submitted to the State Chancellor's Office for final approval.
	 
These courses have met Foothill’s curriculum standards and the Foothill College Curriculum Committee certifies that they are compliant with Title 5 regulations.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, Foothill College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe upon, or impede the educational process. The intent is for the college to utilize facilities more effectively, maximize rental revenue and provide our community and organizations appropriate access to campus facilities.
	 
Foothill College annually reviews and revises the Facility Use Policy, Fees, and procedures that govern rental facilities. Attached is the revised 2015-2016 facilities rental fee schedule.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President, Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Vice President, Finance & Administrative Services, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Representatives from the district's General Obligation Bond underwriters, Morgan Stanley, and the district's bond sale financial advisor, KNN Public Finance, will present a closing summary report of the August 2015 sale of the refunding general obligation bonds (of bonds originally issued and sold as authorized by passage of the district's 2006 Measure C General Obligation Bond elections). The District successfully sold $83,100,000 refunding general obligation bonds producing total savings of $7.4 million to District taxpayers.
	 
Proceeds of the bonds will be used to pay for the advance refunding of a portion of the District's outstanding Election of 2006 General Obligation Bonds, Series A and B, and the payment of costs of issuance of the Bonds. The net proceeds of the Bonds will be deposited into an escrow fund and applied to pay the principal of and interest on the refunding bonds as they become due and to pay redemption prices on the refunding bonds at their respective next available redemption dates.
	 
The refunding will reduce debt service through 2031 by an annual average of $464,547. These savings will result in a tax rate reduction of approximately $0.23/$100,000 of current assessed value.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
 John Sheldon, Morgan Stanley
 Joanna Bowes, KNN Public Finance, Financial Advisor
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_text: 2015 General Obligation Refinancing Bonds Issuance Closing Report (INFORMATION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Provisions with SB 564 require local agencies to report all external investments on a quarterly basis.  In accordance with the aforementioned requirement, attached is a listing of the District’s investments as of June 30, 2015.
	 
The District’s cash, in the amount of $209,942,208.99, is invested in the County’s Commingled Investments Pool.  As of on June 30, 2015, the current yield on the commingled investments pool was 0.62%.  As a comparison to the same time period, the yield on a two-year Treasury Note was 0.65%; the yield on a 6-month Treasury Bill was 0.11%; and the State of California Local Agency Investment Fund (LAIF) yield was 0.30%.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
 
On February 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees (Board) approved Swinerton Builders’ (Swinerton) Preconstruction Services contract for the L-7 Renovation project. On April 6, 2015, the Board approved Swinerton’s Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) and authorized the District to enter into Lease Agreements to construct the L-7 Renovation project. Under the two Lease agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to Swinerton and in return Swinerton agreed to construct Phase 1 of the project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Swinerton’s responses to RFQ/RFP #1678-202. The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made. The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the project at which time the leases will be terminated.
	 
On May 4, 2015, the Board of Trustees (Board) approved Swinerton Builder’s Amendment #1 to the Preconstruction Services for the Phase 2 portion of the project. Swinerton will develop a Construction Schedule for bridging Phase 1 work with Phase 2, proceed with reviewing the Phase 2 design documentation for constructability, prequalify subcontractors for bidding, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, and develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for Phase 2 of the project. Swinerton’s fee for Revision #1 to the Preconstruction Services for Phase 2 is $46,540. The Preconstruction Services Agreement, paragraph VII(C), provides that the contractor will be reimbursed at actual cost for reimbursable services and is defined (in Phase 2) as providing Subcontractor’s engineered design support for the replacement of the raised floors and for the replacement of the Halon fire suppression system – both of which require design completion along with submission and approvals from the Division of the State Architect (DSA). Swinerton proposed and District staff agreed that Swinerton’s reimbursable services for this effort is estimated at $7,500 but should not exceed $10,000.  The total not-to-exceed cost for the Preconstruction Services Agreement was established at $56,540.
	 
Amendment #2 to the Preconstruction Services adds costs for the design-assist portion of the Halon System and raised floor of the Phase 2 portion of the project. The added fee for Amendment #2 to the Preconstruction Services is $15,000 as a reimbursable fee. The additional costs are due to project schedule requirements and added criteria in scope.  Amendment #2 increases the Swinerton’s reimbursable services for this engineered design support effort by $15,000 making the total not-to-exceed value of $25,000 for this effort. 
	 
The budget has been established for the Phase 2 efforts and the value of the Preconstruction services by Swinerton is available within the Phase 2 budget. 
	 
If authorized by the Board, the District will provide and Swinerton will sign Amendment #2 to the Preconstruction Services Agreement and will commence working to complete design of the Halon Suppression System and raised floor and proceed with submission to the Department of the State Architect (DSA).
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones Dulin, Associate Vice President - College Operations
Tom Armstrong, Director - Bond Program Management at De Anza College
					Steve Kitchen, Executive Director - Facilities and Operations

items.item_text: Amendment #2 to the Lease-Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement for L-7 Renovation project at De Anza College to include Phase 2
items.item_text_raw: G) Amendment #2 to the Lease-Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement for L-7 Renovation project at De Anza College to include Phase 2

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #1
Vendor:  Swinerton Builders
Agreement Date:  04/07/2015
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  202
Project Name:  L-7
Amount:  $158,024
For:
 
In order to meet district business operational needs, this Change Order brings Phase 2 work into Phase 1. This Change Order includes 7 PCIs. PCI 11 added work due to CCD #1 for architectural changes to replace doors, windows, and window-mounted A/C units with infill walls at the South offices and IDF room; and, added mechanical split system for the South offices and associated architectural work due to these changes. PCI 12 adds abatement work to the Electrical Room and PCI 17 adds abatement of floor of the future UPS room – both will accommodate future changes in the rooms. PCI 18 adds a Milestone #3 to the project schedule to modify the Substantial Completion of the Non-Classroom portion of L-7 and adds (46) calendar days of compensable General Conditions. PCI 21 adds work due to CCD #2 for adding a diesel-fueled emergency generator for the Machine Room - for submittals and procurement only. PCI 35 is for Architectural Supplementary Instructions #1 that adds a Bypass Switch to the Automatic Transfer Switch at the added emergency generator. PCI 38 adds Milestone #1 to maintain Substantial Completion of the Classrooms by the original September 1, 2015 date and adds Milestone #2 to define Final Completion and allows for full occupancy of the Classrooms by September 21, 2015 – No added General Condition costs are necessary.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: Swinerton Builders - Change Order #1 - L-7 - $158,024
items.item_text_raw: H) Swinerton Builders - Change Order #1 - L-7 - $158,024

Funding for this change is included in the project budget.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
An existing ten-foot wide sanitary sewer easement crosses the Education Center site.  The City of Sunnyvale has requested that the easement width be increased in width to conform to current City standards.  It is in the District’s best interest to increase the easement width to allow future replacement or maintenance of the sanitary sewer line, and this width has been accommodated in the project design.
	 
The dedication of this five-foot wide easement adjacent to the existing ten-foot wide easement will provide the 15-foot wide access corridor requested by the City.
	 
Education Code Section 81310 authorizes the Board of Trustees to dedicate such an easement to a public utility.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Art Heinrich
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director Kitchen recommends that a sanitary sewer easement be granted to the City of Sunnyvale at the FHDA Education Center in Sunnyvale, California.
items.item_text: Foothill-De Anza Education Center – Dedication of Sanitary Sewer Easement to City of Sunnyvale (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 17. Foothill-De Anza Education Center – Dedication of Sanitary Sewer Easement to City of Sunnyvale (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project would require the contractor to drill a 10” diameter borehole approximately 300’ deep for the purpose of locating underground water sources on the Foothill College campus to tie into existing irrigation.  The drill depth of the well is longer than the average depth and it is anticipated that the drilling will penetrate through rock. The scope of work would also require minor electrical work to install a submersible pump and minor concrete work to prepare and pour a concrete pad for the well and electrical connections.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 10 and April 17, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 14, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Only one (1) contractor submitted a bid, Calstate Construction, Inc., at a price of $149,500 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount.
	 
Due to the high cost of the project, the Board of Trustee members concerns over the use of water, and the drought situation affecting the State of California, it is recommended that the District not move forward with the award of this bid.   
	 
According to Public Contract Code, Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.”
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services - x6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen - x6150, Art Heinrich - x6295, Jennifer Mahato - x6178, Gina Bailey - x6165
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject all bids for Bid Document 1729-100M – Well Drilling & Development at Foothill College.
items.item_text: Reject all bids for Bid Document 1729-100M – Well Drilling & Development at Foothill College (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 18. Reject all bids for Bid Document 1729-100M – Well Drilling & Development at Foothill College (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
If awarded, this project will provide the Senior Staff and division deans with the ability to lock-down buildings from identified locations for several instructional buildings, division offices, the Campus Center, the Child Development Center, and the Administration Building in the event of a police action or emergency situation.  The project will also provide the technologies and capabilities for Plant Services personnel to more effectively and efficiently program the locks and control access from a remote location. 
	 
The scope of work consists of a variety of modifications to building entries including replacing electronic door locksets and retrofitting existing door hardware; installing electrical and data cabling; replacing wood doors with hollow metal doors; removing and replacing new aluminum swinging doors; modifying door thresholds to be compliant with current ADA access requirements; installing remote lock-down push buttons; integrating and programming the added security hardware with the recently purchased Access Control System software; installing control panels to support devices including card readers, locks, and door position monitoring; and, providing network cabling to devices for network communications to the campus controls infrastructure.  Keller and Daseking Architects, along with access control systems technical experts at Charles Salter Associates, designed the project and prepared the bid specifications.   
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on June 5, June 12, July 7, and July 14, 2015 in the San Jose Post Record. Several Builders Exchanges and Contractors also received notification that they could receive bid documents through the FHDA portal of the PlanetBids website which is available by selecting "Bid Opportunities" at purchasing.fhda.edu.  Five “B” contractors and several subcontractors attended one of the two job walk opportunities for the project. Bids were publicly opened and read on August 12, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
	 
					 
CONTRACTOR
Base Buildings:
Admin, Forum, PE4, S3, LCW, Planetarium, A4, L1, SCS, VPAC, MCC, Kirsch, ATC, MLC
					 
CDC Buildings
					 
Campus Center
					 
Allowance for Unforeseen Conditions
					 
TOTAL Base Bid Proposal Amount
Calstate Construction, Inc.
$824,456
$115,813
$215,841

$1,191,110.00
					 
Swenson & Associates
$900,512
$115,010

$1,322,435.00
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$995,814
$116,977
$286,538
$35,000
$1,434,329.00
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
The construction estimate for the project is $944,209 for all locations. The apparent low bidder is Calstate Construction, Inc. (Calstate) with a bid price of $1,191,110, which is $246,901 more than the estimate.  Calstate has confirmed that its bid price is true and accurate for the work as specified.  The added costs are most likely attributed to (1) data cabling routing and control panels inside of specific buildings and the inclusion of whole door replacements that were added to the scope of work, (2) the requirement for the work scheduled at CDC to be performed solely during evenings from 6:00 p.m. – 6:00 a.m. and weekends, and (3) repair work to numerous door thresholds to meet current DSA requirements regarding the ADA access points and paths of travel to buildings that was added in the final design stages.
	 
Although, this project came in over the Architect’s estimated value and the allocated Measure C budget, it was planned that the Child Development Center and Campus Center would fund their portions of the construction costs. Because of the safety importance of the project, the Campus will provide additional funding (fund 400) to close the budget shortfall.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Donna Jones Dulin, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
